Project

Design and implement a multiplayer online game. The graphics must use Pygame, and it must be in 2D, not 3D. You pick the process (Waterfall, iterative, ...), as long as there is progress. Oral report with your group every week during discussion. Here is a list of games and applications not too difficult to clone:

Bomberman/WiiU Pikmin Adventure (co-op or player versus player) Canabalt Checkers/Chess (problem: it's only 2 players) Connect Four (if you manage to make a version for N simultaneous players)
Dots and Boxes Duck Hunt Fishing derby (2-player problem) Flobo Puyo/Tetris/Quadra (2-player problem)
IRC Chat (can be arbitrarily complex, very flexible GUI: tkinter, curses, or pygame) Jigsaw Lunar Lander Pong (with more than 2 players)
Scrabble/Words with Friends (more than 2 players) Snake Space Invaders Space Race
Tag/WiiU Mario Chase/WiiU Animal Crossing: Sweet Day Text editor Tic tac toe (maybe too easy) Frogger
Atari 2600 games More Atari 2600 Mario Party mini games

Four milestones:
4/8: Pick a game by the end of discussion in week 2.
4/22: I expect a playable single-player demo by week 4. The single-player demo should not need an AI. Think of it as a hotseat game if it's turn-based (like Scrabble or Tic tac toe). For games with moving avatars (like Bomberman), think that one player controls the arrows and another WASD. You can even make a boring single-player version of the game if it was originally multiplayer (like Pong against a wall). I want a single-player version first so that you are comfortable with the GUI before you add the networking mess.
5/20: A playable multi-player demo by week 8. Feature freeze: don't add any new functionality after this date. Grade based on progress, knowledge of the code, and justification of your architectural choices. The WHOLE team must be here.
6/2 and 6/4: Presentation in class: I'll send the URL of all project repos to all students. For each project, all students will download the code and connect to your server (you'll write the ip:port of your server on the whiteboard). Your grade is based on how well your game accomodates the 20 players for at least 5 minutes, and on the feedback received by other students through their answer sheet.
